Now that I've just rambled on about the service, I'll leave a few lines for the food. To be honest, not much to say really. Good halummi and humous sandwich (though to be honest it was primarily spinach with three pieces of halummi and a thin layer of humous) and the coffee was satisfactory. In the end, I left less than impressed, and with slim chances of every returning. Bah humbug.

BH617gm07QIB4TyJMTg5ng.text: The Breakfast Club Soho is a cheerfully painted yellow cafe that offers an array of choice for breakfast and lunch. Uber-cool media types tend to pop in here for a quiet drink and chat or a hearty breakfast.The cafe offers sandwiches, smoothies, salads and the traditional English fry-up, which I chose to have this time. The eggs were on the good side of runny, toast chunky, baked beans plentiful and I washed this down with a mint tea. My friend Kate, also had a fry-up with fresh orange-juice. You get a lot for your money here, given the location and the staff are friendly and very polite. The atmosphere is very relaxed and I would definitely recommend the cafe to people who just want a chilled atmosphere to catch up with a bunch of friends on any given day. It tends to get very busy during lunchtime however, it's pretty much expected given its popularity.

photos.caption: Photo of The Breakfast Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Breakfast Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Breakfast Club - London, United Kingdom

53GRi6BqNl6mMpv0yPPTXw.text: If you wake up hungry but patient, this is the place for you. Fantastically large servings of american-style breakfasts and brunches in an extremely casual setting. The line, however, is a big one.For those less adventurous/gut-busting, the museli is great, and there are a number of non-fried options.

EnbDLhoC2UdSar2ND2TLcw.text: Oh Breakfast Cafe, you hold a special place in my heart. While I'll agree with the other yelpers that it's not the most delicious, amazing breakfast you've ever had, for London standards, it hits the spot.Come here if you want a hearty, greasy brunch that is sure to give you food coma afterwards.I came with a friend on a Tuesday morning. It wasn't too crowded and the service was fast and friendly (keeping in mind that service in London tends to be abominable, this might be one of the few times where I was happy with it). I ordered the Scrambled Eggs and Salmon, which was so big that I pretty much passed out afterward. Had the Mango Go smoothie too, which was okay, but you won't miss much if you didn't try it. My friend had the Pancakes with fruit-- came as a stack of 4. I had a bite and actually liked it (though if you're a fan of only the light fluffy kind, I can see how you wouldn't like it). Would definitely come back :)

HKYiR8d2Sh44X1fUdo9gDA.text: I love pancakes (and I don't mean crepes. Well, I love crepes too, but in a different context. This time, I mean the thick, puffy, carby discs, doused in maple syrup, that are apparently not called 'pancakes' anywhere else in the world but North America). Despite the fact that I rarely eat pancakes, I have been craving them for, now, five months -- a craving so long and miserable, yet so decidedly ignored until today.After waiting outside of the nearby Apollo Theatre for nearly three hours this morning (look out for my review of that, which will come shortly after I see a show there tonight), some friends and I decided that we deserved a hot, filling breakfast and a very large caffeinated beverage. Two clicks on the Yelp app later, and a short walk down Berwick Avenue, and we arrived outside of the bright yellow, exceedingly friendly-looking establishment that is the Breakfast Club Soho. Upon entering the restaurant, we were greeted by a very smiley, hipster server (how do these things go together? cannot compute) and immediately shown to our tiny-and-squashed-in-a-corner table. To be fair, since the restaurant would make a hobbit hole look like Versailles, all of the tables are shoved in some sort of corner, and are awkwardly close to one another. We were then approached by an even smilier, multiply-facially-pierced and heavily tattooed server (everything I've known about trendy people has been a lie) to get our food and drink orders. Since a few of us had a difficult time deciding amongst the menu's numerous brunch favorites, such as huevos rancheros, breakfast burritos, eggs benedict, and more, the server took time to give recommendations/explanations and point out which dishes she liked best. As I said before, with pancakes on the brain, there was no question about what I was getting. Hence, I ordered the Ham so Eggsited (and boy, was I) -- pancakes with cheddar, ham, and a fried egg -- but switched out the ham for some hash browns. I wasn't expecting what came next, but I'm not sorry it did. Sooo, very, completely un-sorry. The cheese (and I'm assuming the ham, normally, as well) was slapped between each of the three pancakes, and melted to perfection with residual heat. The fried egg was artfully placed on top, with the yolk running everywhere. Lastly, this magnificent delicacy was placed in a golden pool of maple syrup, soaking in all of its sweetness (and high fructose corn syrup). Oh, and the hash browns (which are really home fries, as Jenn mentioned below) were served in a dish on the side. BUT I STILL PUT THEM ON THE MAPLE SYRUPY PLATE ANYWAY (clearly, living on the edge). The resulting combination was the perfect mixture of savory and sweet, crispy and fluffy, sticky and smooth. It was a party in my mouth. No, actually, a full on rave.This meal, which could have easily fed two, along with my Americano, was £10 exactly. I have spent more than that at one go on packets of M&S biscuits and Percy the Pig sweets. While I couldn't afford to eat like this every day (both for the sake of my bank account and my arteries), I'd say it's a pretty good value for money. And it scratched my nearly half-year pancake itch, so there are no complaints here.Go to Breakfast Club Soho! Will check out the Hoxton and Angel locations soon to compare awesomeness levels.

TMlBXOyr7KL3x6uhMJP4pA.text: I love The Breakfast Club, specifically the one in Shoreditch! Been there too many times to count. And I've been to the Soho location twice for brunch, but it's definitely a long line so leave about an hour or two for breakfast. I prefer the East London location to this one based on service and wait time, but the food is just as great!

LorUtkoc3VTXYP5FaSqDXw.text: This has got to be one of the most popular places around. Busy in the morning before work, the crowds thin only slightly after the working day begins. A popular spot for social media typs, this place has that funky vibe that really declares independance from staid and traditional coffee shops. I have yet to sample their fare but the coffee and atmosphere is just fantastic and for that alone I recommend this place!

OQBUOChtKV7FUMx-IPxR5w.text: coffee and cappuccino - CHECKfresh squeezed orange juice - CHECKveggie breakfast with pancakes? - SKIPthe veggetarian sausages were the only upside to that dish. crisp on the outside, and a nutty mush inside was tasty, but i wouldn't get again. the scrambled eggs were a-ok, -0- salt, and oily. the grilled mushroom was a grease-soaked-grilled-sponge with truly very LITTLE flavor :-/and the pancakes??? omg... seriously don't even get me started..... i thought i would leave sweetness for last... boy was i WRONG... (or right?)) idk... they were drier and harder than brick. NOT kidding. seirously i tried to break them with a knife ... and just honestly thought it would fly off my plate before breaking... two resilient pancakes they were, lemme tell you (my friend even took a picture of me trying to break my way into them). Then i thought, what the heck, I will just eat them ummm like cookies..and i think my teeth would break before the pancakes would.sooooo dissappointed... especially after reading these reviews :(the ambiance is very friendly, and warm, just the kind of place, I would sit to sip coffee and read a magazine, but i think i will have to try some of the other things on the menu... as i was truly disappointed by the veggie breakfast, and reggie veggie :-(also BE PREPARED TO WAIT!!! the coffee took almost 20 minutes and the food over 36 mins from the time of order... so don't come hungry... that's the idea.the waitresses are friendly, cozy interior, and great fresh OJ. won't come back :-/

81yhktu71UzhslU9f50W8w.text: Dear Breakfast Club,Your pancakes are fantastic, sprinkled lightly with cinnamon and faking healthiness with your dollop of Greek yogurt and fresh fruit. You, in fact, lied though, drugging me with sugary syrup sending my glucose levels through the roof and then dropping me to the floor.  I was left with the inability to stay awake at work. Who knew all-day breakfast required an afternoon nap?Your tea was generous in size, your ambience, inviting but I second what Linzi M. had to say, your "Hippie's Exit" sign is cute, but not cute enough to make sitting next to the door a good feature. What can I say,  us Canadians are suckers for pancakes and yours really do runnith over.

bbRq3X8Ke3yQzelEZn7uLA.text: The only place I have EVER been able to find Halloumi cheese in a sandwich/wrap (if only it were GRILLED...).  Here, it is put together with sundried tomatoes, mixed leaf  & hummous to excellent effect.  Centrally located, and free Wi-Fi, too.  I'm lovin' it...

8tEZvXSp3cgPlioYhgZHjA.text: The best chai latte I've ever had, hands down. This place is always good! Fun, cozy, affordable and friendly service. Same thing goes for the one on Camden Passage.

zM6YgpTro-8IR2MqzFmxDA.text: The Breakfast Club is a real delight in the heart of Soho - surrounded by chain sandwich stores (you know who you are) and generic cafes, The Breakfast Club retains it's unique, quirky charm which has made it so popular.  Cosy and terribly funky, The Breakfast Club has a super-cute menu boasting big breakfast and really tasty sandwiches.  Check out the Soup of the Day too, it's always super special. Good quality coffee and teas, along with smoothies and juices make this the perfect place to relax after (or during!) a hard day's shopping in Soho.

4Nc8PU2FIIAXjfrXfZiJ3w.text: Have visited the Breakfast club a few times before the most recently being this weekend Word of warning... tables on a weekend are near impossible to get so be prepared to wait or go early! Especially if you have a party of 3 or more as most of the tables are for 2. We went at about 11am on Sunday since nothing opens in London til about 11/12 but wished we went at 9 when it opened as the queue had about 6 people before us and from what I could see through the window everyone had just started eating! Anyway went back the next day and got a table no problem. The decor is very kitsch and 'cluttered' with mismatched tables and chairs and with only about 9 or 10 tables in the cafe it is certainly small! Ordered orange juice, pancakes, granola and a full monty breakfast. Yes the food takes a while to come which I actually quite like as you can tell it's cooked to demand. The orange juice was freshly squeezed too. Portions are very large! It took 3 people to finish off my granola with yogurt and berries as it was so big! Pancakes came with fresh berries, yogurt, and a little pot of maple syrup (I hate it when places pour the syrup on the pancakes as they just soak it up instantly and the pancakes taste dry) Full Monty breakfast had 2 fried eggs with runny yolks and big doorstopper slices of bread along with beans, sausages, bacon etc I would say very good value for money especially for the portion sizesPancakes were just under £5, Granola was £4 and Full Monty was £8 Definately recommened just be prepared to wait!!

85YN3AABXXV6YQf8qVrcLg.text: I had an all american breakfast here - eggs, pancake, etc. all was good. nothing spectacular though.

X7pdKbSsZfaJD_7uSEuxIQ.text: The Breakfast Club; no, I'm not talking about the greatest teen movie ever produced.  I'm talking about this really cute and funky café in Soho.  It has fresh orange juice, good sandwiches, even better coffee and hearty breakfasts.  They also have really cute buttons that you can attach to your knapsack that say 'The Breakfast Club' on it.  It looks all rustic, with rusty pig feeding buckets, yellow walls, vintage wooden tables and cool odd knick knacks like troll dolls adorning the interior.  The food isn't half bad either, although I warn that the sausages are kind of rank.  I don't know what that sow on my plate was eating from the trough and I don't even want to think about it.  Generally the staff is really nice too, but most of the time they are understaffed at this particular restaurant for some reason (especially on Saturdays), so expect to wait a long time before you get your food and before the food on your table left by the party before you gets cleared away.

photos.caption: Photo of The Breakfast Club - London, United Kingdom

RlYWynY6t9iciVeWqseC_w.text: What a cool place to go for breakfast, I'm surprised I've only just found out about the place, what with the film being one of my favourites! English or American, the breakfast doesn't disappoint and the please has a really friendly and informal atmosphere to it. Worth going to if you take pride in the most important meal of the day. Coffee is decent also.

IZStAgTiBOtBQTRMUOEiXQ.text: Right after a decent flat white at milk bar, i feel a bit hungry so i decide to went in to have a quick bite here. The food was great especially breakfast burrito, remind me when i was in State what a great time i had over there.

AoJx_-Z2Jk12ka70lrqbaQ.text: A wonderful little breakfast place right in the middle of Soho that I hadn't discovered until now when introduced to it by a fellow Qyper. Great selection of everything you could want for a hearty breakfast. They make a lovely cup of coffee and the scrambled eggs were pretty good too. I wouldn't say they were perfect or anywhere near the best eggs I've ever had, but they were good enough and did the trick on a rainy hungover Friday morning. It came with an interesting side of tomato relish, which was ok but straight out of the fridge so a bit too cold for the poor little eggs! The smoothies looked amazing so I'll be coming back for one of those soon. Cute scruffy décor with a retro feel, a great place to come for a yummy breakfast in Soho.

h8Debhxc61aHSf7gXhO4jA.text: Kitch. Slightly contrived. Delicious Yogurt, museli and banana breakfast. Media crowd. Excellent selection of cooked breakfast if you need grease. Not too shy to have brown sauce. Excellent coffee.

xRyRnznd3bA6UoRMsKWetg.text: Meh, I think I've been in San Francisco for too long.I'd been craving a real English breakfast to make up for the many American brunches I'd eaten in the last six months. Sadly, this one didn't quite hit the button.First we stood at the front of the store for about 3 minutes before any of the 3 staff at the counter even acknowledged us (or moved out of the way so that we could seat ourselves). The waitress was beyond flaky. And the breakfast was only so-so. Oh well. If I could go back to Zazie's I would.

OKIoWYIOezUCPoxEPUTsqg.text: A great place for any time of day, not just for breakfast! The eclectic decor, great food and location are just right for a either a mid-shop lunch for those who start early, or a meeting spot for those who don't often see the morning!! And the fact tht it doesn't do alcohol makes it the perfect get away spot for the morning after the night before for those of us for whom the hair of the dog is more hinderance than help!Food is wholesome, filling, tasty and cheap (ie amazing!) and the service is always very friendly, if not always totally on the ball I also have had to chase up drink orders in this joint!A regular haunt wrapped up in pretty paper and tied with a bow. With bacon.

j12sQQ983trbiC7FIfb75w.text: Love the pancakes, love the smoothies. They do a great selection of quick pre-made take-away stuff for Soho employees on the go. They have nice yoghurt pots and freshly squeezed juices and smoothies. I get coffee from here somtimes. This branch is much cosier than their newer Islington location. Here you'll find couches and benches to relax and enjoy the free wi-fi.

jhSag2QOP99IubMgwnKJDw.text: the pastrami on toasted rye is awesome and the waitstaff are quirky and endearing!

xUOjyChJxA4AGC4BOrHpyA.text: At £3.50 for a veggie sausage sandwich on delictable doorstop cut grainery (which they'll even toast if you're so inclined), you can't go wrong with Breakfast (or lunch or afternoon tea) at The Breakfast Club. Delicious, wholesome food with experimental Breakfast combos (pancakes in a Full English?) that just seem to work this place will put a smile on your face that will last the day. Free wifi, and the staff will happily let you linger over a coffee - they do mean smoothies too!

AMIqwpoAnchXUEEYxnmpdw.text: Love this place. Good brekky, good cake, you can choose your own music on the iMacs, and free internet and wifi. And more importantly, the prices are significantly lower than you'd expect, more great portion sizes. Try the carrot cake, and the scrambled eggs, and fresh orange juice.

WOwsMmiNJapg5NqUsVszOA.text: The pancakes were burnt, the eggs were overcooked, and the service was slow.  Oh, and the menu is not very imaginative. I had high hopes for an American-style diner experience, but an average Waffle House in Georgia can do a better job.
